Our assumption with Heritrix has been to provide default policies that 
obey common-convention robots-rules with respect to all *collecting* 
activity, such as over-the-network fetching/crawling.

This means:
� don't fetch URLs prohibited by robots.txt rules
� don't follow outbound links from a page with a 
META[name=robots,content*=nofollow]

We haven't tried to implement any interpretation of robots-rules to 
control the *storing* of content, once allowably fetched.

In particular, the interpretation of a tag like 'NOARCHIVE' is not 
straightforward.

As far as I know, there's no canonical/authoritative declaration of what 
'NOARCHIVE' should mean. (In contrast, NOINDEX/NOFOLLOW are documented, 
at least a little, via reports of a consensus discussion at 
robotstxt.org. [1])

I believe that 'NOARCHIVE' was introduced by Google, and adoption by 
others has been spotty.

And, for Google, it does NOT mean "don't store this info in any form". 
Rather, it means, "don't display a cached version of this page to the 
public". [2] Google still retrieves and indexes the full contents of 
'NOARCHIVE' pages, and (in one sliced-and-diced form or another) has 
what amounts to an internal copy of the content.

As a result, if we are following Google's lead as the creator of this 
'NOARCHIVE' tag, we should make the tag automatically cause the material 
to be discarded at crawl time. Rather, the tag should be considered at 
either index-for-display or redisplay time, and prevent the sharing of 
cached material.

Indeed, that's what we do for Heritrix: only consider the robots rules 
that limit initial collection, leaving decisions on storage and access 
for other software. Both the classic (closed-source) Wayback, and the 
new open-source Wayback software, will usually observe a 'NOARCHIVE' 
directive inside HTML META tags during URL-indexing, as meaning a 
document should be left out of public display. (The content remains 
stored for other potential purposes.)

If an archive in an abundance of caution wanted to discard fetched 
content with a NOARCHIVE tag such that it is never even stored, that 
would be a fairly easy option to add to Heritrix. I'd be open to that as 
a feature, but for the reasons above, we might not want that to be the 
default crawl-time behavior.

Hope this helps,

- Gordon @ IA

[1] http://www.robotstxt.org/meta.html ...and...
http://www.robotstxt.org/metabof.html

[2] See Google's help text at:
http://www.google.com/support/webmasters/bin/answer.py?answer=79812
